ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Automatically setting the Speciation Threshold

X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Ian Badcoe wrote:


>Why does this 
>matter?  Well, for example, each evolving species is a population, 
>with a variety of different individuals in it, that's how its search 
>works, but as soon as we assign species by direct comparison, we 
>suddenly define the members of the species as all being similar to 
>some degree (and we also prevent any other species from exploring the 
>same individuals).  So I wonder if we hamper our species by being too 
>precise in how we assign individuals.
>  
>
I don't think the degree of precision is ever problem but the means of 
comparison may be.

>Anyway, to get back a point or two.  "Species" created by comparisons 
>would seem better named as "categories" to me, e.g. because that's 
>what we did, we categorised the population...
>  
>
The terms species and speciation fit in nicely with what we're doing. 
It's just that right now we speciate based upon the results of a 
comparison.We're splitting hairs a bit here eh :)

To recap, the main idea I'm getting from this discussion is that we 
might see benefits from more clever speciation techniques. I suspect the 
current scheme is fine for the plain old non-modular NEAT genome because 
it is so small and the same structures are likely arrived at 
independently via different lineages - and we want to keep those similar 
structures in the same species, otherwise we have redundant species.

However,  I suspect the sorts of issues you raise become relevant when 
using indirect encodings where small changes in the genome are able to 
cause dramatic changes. You maybe need some way of tagging bits of the 
genome as being more important when comparing (evolved comparison 
weights), and ultimately you might want to shortcut the comparison 
procedure by setting species ID's once a species has existed for some 
amount of time - this means from now on you don't bother comparing with 
a genome that doesn't have that ID. This is a bit more like nature then 
in that we have hard lines drawn between groups - once you draw the line 
(define a species) there is no crossing back into another group.

Colin.
